name: Akara & Pap (Bean Cakes with Fermented Corn Porridge)
description: Crispy golden-brown bean cakes paired with smooth, slightly tangy pap (ogi). A classic Nigerian breakfast.
ingredients: 2 cups peeled beans (black-eyed peas or brown beans)
steps: Soak peeled beans in water for about 10 minutes, then blend with onions and peppers until smooth and thick.
Season the paste with salt and stir vigorously for 5 minutes to incorporate air — this makes the akara fluffy.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep pan until moderately hot (test with a drop of batter; it should sizzle immediately).
Scoop spoonfuls of the bean paste gently into the oil, making sure not to overcrowd the pan.
Fry on medium heat until the edges turn golden brown, then flip and fry the other side until crispy and fully cooked inside.
Drain akara on paper towels and serve hot with freshly prepared pap (ogi).

name: Moi Moi (Steamed Bean Pudding)
description: Steamed bean pudding made with ground beans, peppers, and spices, often wrapped in leaves or foil.
ingredients: Moi Moi leaves or aluminum foil
steps: Blend peeled beans, red bell peppers, and onion with water until you achieve a smooth paste.
Add palm oil, crayfish, seasoning cubes, and salt. Mix thoroughly to create a rich batter.
Scoop batter into moi moi leaves (folded into cones) or greased aluminum foil containers.
Arrange the wrapped batter in a large pot, add water to the bottom (without submerging), and cover tightly.
Steam on low to medium heat for 45–60 minutes, checking water level occasionally and topping up if necessary.
Test doneness by inserting a toothpick in the center — it should come out clean. Serve warm with pap, bread, or rice.

name: Agege Bread with Akamu (Pap)
description: Soft, chewy Agege bread served with smooth pap (ogi) — a true Lagos breakfast staple.
steps: Prepare pap by mixing the fermented corn paste with cold water, stirring to form a slurry.
Boil water and pour gradually into the slurry while stirring continuously until thick and smooth.
Sweeten pap with sugar or honey and add a splash of evaporated milk if desired.
Serve hot with soft slices of Agege bread on the side.

name: Jollof Rice
description: Smoky Nigerian party-style Jollof rice cooked in a rich tomato-pepper base.
steps: Blend tomatoes, bell peppers, scotch bonnets, and one onion into a smooth paste.
Heat oil in a large pot, sauté sliced onions until fragrant, then add the blended paste.
Fry the mixture on medium heat until it reduces and the oil begins to float to the top — about 12–15 minutes.
Stir in thyme, curry, seasoning cubes, and stock. Mix well.
Add parboiled rice, stir to coat with sauce, then cover with foil or parchment before placing the pot lid to trap steam.
Cook on low heat until rice is tender and smoky. Stir occasionally to prevent burning, but a little bottom crust is desirable.
Serve hot with fried plantains, salad, or grilled chicken.

name: Ofada Rice with Ayamase (Designer Stew)
description: Local unpolished Ofada rice served with spicy green pepper stew (Ayamase).
steps: Cook Ofada rice in salted water until soft. Rinse off excess starch if necessary.
Blend green bell peppers, scotch bonnets, and one onion into a coarse paste.
Heat palm oil until slightly bleached (about 5 minutes on medium heat).
Add sliced onions and fry until translucent, then stir in the pepper blend.
Cook on medium heat, stirring often, until the stew thickens and the raw taste disappears.
Add cooked assorted meats, seasoning cubes, and salt. Simmer for 10–15 minutes.
Serve piping hot with Ofada rice.

name: Egusi Soup with Pounded Yam
description: Rich melon seed soup cooked with vegetables and assorted meats, best enjoyed with pounded yam.
steps: Mix ground egusi with a little water to form a thick paste.
Heat palm oil in a pot and add the egusi paste, frying gently until it becomes grainy and aromatic.
Blend peppers and onion into a smooth mixture and add to the egusi. Stir well.
Pour in meat stock and add meats and stockfish. Simmer on medium heat for 15 minutes.
Add vegetable leaves, seasoning cubes, and salt. Stir and cook for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot with freshly pounded yam.

name: Efo Riro (Spinach Stew)
description: A Yoruba-style spinach stew cooked with palm oil, peppers, and meats.
steps: Blend peppers and onion into a coarse paste.
Heat palm oil in a pot and fry the mixture until it reduces and thickens.
Add meats or fish and pour in a little stock. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add chopped spinach, stir, and cook for just 3–5 minutes to preserve nutrients and color.
Serve hot with rice, yam, or amala.

name: Okra Soup
description: Delicious slimy okra soup prepared with meats, palm oil, and leafy greens.
steps: Chop okra finely or blend lightly for a slimy texture.
Cook meats and fish with onions, seasoning, and stock until tender.
Add palm oil and stir in the okra, cooking on low heat while stirring continuously.
Add ugu leaves and adjust seasoning. Cook for 3 more minutes.
Serve with eba, amala, or pounded yam.

name: Ogbono Soup
description: Rich, drawy soup made from ground ogbono seeds.
steps: Heat palm oil gently in a pot, then stir in ground ogbono until it dissolves.
Add stock gradually while stirring to avoid lumps. The soup should thicken and draw.
Add cooked meats, stockfish, and seasoning. Simmer on low heat for 15 minutes.
Add leafy greens last and cook for 5 minutes.
Serve hot with pounded yam, eba, or semo.

name: Nsala Soup (White Soup)
description: A light, peppery soup made without palm oil, common among the Igbo people.
steps: Boil yam cubes until soft, then pound into a smooth paste for thickening.
Cook catfish or chicken with seasoning until tender.
Add crayfish, ground pepper, and yam paste to the pot. Stir well.
Add utazi leaves last for aroma and slight bitterness.
Serve hot with pounded yam or fufu.

name: Suya
description: Spicy, smoky skewered beef grilled with suya spice mix.
steps: Marinate beef slices in groundnut oil and suya spice mix for at least 1 hour.
Thread beef onto skewers and grill over open flame or in an oven until fully cooked and slightly charred.
Sprinkle extra suya spice and serve hot with sliced onions, tomatoes, and cucumber.

name: Puff-Puff
description: Sweet, fluffy deep-fried dough balls, a favorite Nigerian street snack.
steps: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, and nutmeg in a bowl.
Add warm water gradually to form a thick but smooth batter.
Cover the bowl with a cloth and let it rise for 1 hour until doubled in size.
Heat oil in a deep pan and scoop batter in small portions.
Fry until golden brown and drain on paper towels.
Serve warm, optionally dusted with powdered sugar.

name: Chin Chin
description: Crunchy fried snack made from flour, sugar, and milk.
steps: Mix flour, sugar, milk, butter, and egg into a smooth dough.
Roll out dough and cut into small cubes or strips.
Fry in hot oil until golden brown and crispy.
Cool completely and store in airtight container.

name: Nigerian Meat Pie
description: Buttery pastry filled with minced meat, potatoes, and carrots.
steps: Prepare the filling by frying onions, minced beef, carrots, and potatoes until cooked. Season well.
Make pastry by mixing flour, baking powder, butter, and water into a dough.
Roll out dough, cut circles, and place filling inside each.
Fold into half-moon shapes and seal edges with a fork.
Brush with beaten egg and bake at 180°C for 30–35 minutes until golden.

name: Zobo Drink (Hibiscus Tea)
description: Refreshing drink made from hibiscus petals, ginger, and spices.
steps: Rinse hibiscus petals thoroughly and place in a large pot.
Add water, ginger, cloves, and pineapple peels. Bring to a boil and simmer for 30 minutes.
Strain the liquid and discard solids.
Sweeten with sugar or honey while still warm, then chill in the fridge.
Serve cold with ice cubes.
